subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Tap sound
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_002E_01C9E1D4.693FB930
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

I was only talking about remote PK phenomena as being very rare, not all PK=
 phenomena. Still, any type of paranormal phenomena is rare, so the case co=
uld be made that PK is rare.

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: pheno=
m_investigator 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 31, 2009=
 8:53 AM
  Subject: [EVP-ITC] Re: Tap sound





  I don't wish to belabor =
this point too much further since it is not the focus of this forum. Howeve=
r this is so central to understanding phenomenology and PK does appear to b=
e a potential root cause of at least some EVP and ITC work, so one more com=
ment is in order.

  As part of my research I reanalyzed many previously re=
ported cases. I found a remarkable number where PK (including remote PK) wa=
s a quite plausible explanation. 

  Consider also that in my work this is =
highly replicable phenomena. Replicable phenomena is defined as having a la=
rger effect size than subtle less replicable phenomena. Many forms of mediu=
mship and related psi are correctly defined as small effect size phenomena =
and hence far less replicable. This leads to the requirement to conduct ext=
ensive testing simply to establish correct statistical outcomes.

  However=
 as replicability improves so too does effect size (boiling water being an =
excellent example of a large effect size phenomenon that is of course highy=
 replicable). As effect size and replicability increase the 'rarity' of phe=
nomena is no longer supported. Therefore I would contend, based on the abov=
e that indeed remote PK is in fact far more common than is commonly believe=
d and in fact this nicely explains not a small percentage but in fact a lar=
ge percentage of many anecdotally reported phenomena. 

  --- In EVP-ITC@ya=
hoogroups.com, "April Abercrombie" <april@...> wrote:
  >
  > Yes, I agree =
that it may be possible to have PK events occur remotely. 
  > 
  > Once we=
 have ruled out all mundane explanations, and we think we have actual paran=
ormal phenomena, then we consider what type of paranormal phenomena we are =
dealing with.
  > 
  > The problem with remote PK energy is that it is extr=
emely rare, at least when it is without conscious intent. It is so rare, th=
at it only exists in theory pretty much. It is a WAY more common occurrence=
 that when we find any type of PK energy, it occurs only when the subject i=
s present.
  > 
  > ----- Original Message ----- 
  > From: phenom_investig=
ator 
  > To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  > Sent: Saturday, May 30, 2009 7:1=
5 AM
  > Subject: [EVP-ITC] Re: Tap sound
  > 
  > 
  > 
  > 
  > 
  > It i=
s not commonly understood that PK events do not require a local PK agent. W=
hile this is the far more common phenomenon, it is by no means the only way=
 in which these events can manifest. I personally have conducted rigorous r=
emote PK experiments many times over the years. This remote intention as it=
 has come to be called is quiet real and remarkably replicable with the rig=
ht people. This validated phenomena actually explains quite a few cases tha=
t are generally attributed to other, sometimes far more bizarre causes.
  >=
 
  > Of course it makes sense to look for natural causes. However it is ap=
propriate to consider alternatives if you have fail to locate plausible phy=
sical causations.
  > 
  > --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "April Abercromb=
ie" <april@> wrote:
  > >
  > > There is absolutely no evidence pointing to=
wards PK phenomena. The homeowners were not present during the investigatio=
n. These surges can easily be explained as mundane and therefore we must as=
sume it is. If we can't rule out all mundane sources, then we have to assum=
e it is not paranormal.
  > > 
  > > These were electrical surges. The only=
 time we had EMF spikes was when these taps would be heard. The meter would=
 spike, and then immediately return to 0.
  > > 
  > > "Do your readings in=
 your notes? Were you reading electrical or magnetic
  > > fields? What typ=
e of EMF meter were you using?"
  > > 
  > > Yes we logged all readings. We=
 were reading EMF, so a bit of both. We had several types of meters present=
. At one point, we had 2 KII meters a few feet apart in the living room. On=
 some taps, one would go off, and others, the other one would go off. Most =
spikes fell in the 2.5 mg range, but a couple went off the scale.
  > > 
  =
> > It also explains some of the other activity the homeowners complained a=
bout-the touch lamp, kitchen lights dimming, etc.
  > > 
  > > Again, these=
 surges were constant, though not uniform.
  > > 
  > > April
  > > 
  > > =
----- Original Message ----- 
  > > From: phenom_investigator 
  > > To: EV=
P-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  > > Sent: Thursday, May 28, 2009 10:04 AM
  > > Su=
bject: [EVP-ITC] Re: Tap sound
  > > 
  > > 
  > > 
  > > 
  > > 
  > > Wha=
t I have been hearing on this since the first posting is a single
  > > tap=
 that sounds like wood on wood. Since the tapping was continual
  > > and y=
ou noticed an EM spike there is another possibility.
  > > 
  > > You could=
 have detected a PK event. In poltergeist cases we have come
  > > to reali=
ze that living PK agents often are responsible. These agents
  > > function=
 in environments with specific characteristics and themselves
  > > exhibit=
 specific traits. One of the environmental characteristics is
  > > an elev=
ated magnetic field. Often this is a geomagnetic field as seems
  > > to be=
 the case in extreme poltergeist cases. Less extremem cases, 
  > > such as=
 this may be, we often see elevated EM field levels. Do your
  > > readings=
 in your notes? Were you reading electrical or magnetic
  > > fields? What =
type of EMF meter were you using? This might help
  > > determine if the in=
fo you noticed was potentially related to PK
  > > effects.
  > > 
  > > --=
- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "April Abercrombie" <april@> wrote:
  > > >
 =
 > > > Let's try it again.
  > > >
  > >
  >
